topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54acace863687211fe0e0b00#post_54acace863687211fe0e0b00
As a business, I would look more into their trustworthiness and competence, employees' ability to perform at their jobs above anything else. I could care less what gender, sexuality, or any other backgrounds they are. As most of those details are likely irrelevant to business.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54acad32636872226ecc1100#post_54acad32636872226ecc1100
You're assuming that the people who don't know their asses from a hole in the ground are the ones that will lose their jobs. These are the people who make the decisions, and frankly I don't see them as stepping down. After all, where would we be without dudes in suits incapable of relating to anyone other than dudes in suits telling us what really want?
topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54acaf5f6368723b3f7b0400#post_54acaf5f6368723b3f7b0400
Well obviously; rather what I mean is that a change going on in the macro scale that isn't being talked about right now that much is that computers are taking over a larger and larger portion of the business structure.  To use a analogy it's like how computers are taking over the stock market; nobody is talking about it, but at the rate we're going the NY stock market floor in say ten years is going to be completely devoid of anyone.
